Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: Engagement with social issues
Response.Q6: The tagging without any particular message. Pointless vadalism.
Response.Q8: blues and purples.they make me feel inquisitive to the message
Response.Q10: They are important because they provide a message, whereas the artistic tagging has no real message.
Response.Q14: About families and countrymen divided by meaningless titles.
Response.Q15: People desperately desire peace but are afraid of change
Response.Q16: yes. it starts a conversation at a more engageable level for other social classes

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: Its colourful and creative. It brightens up dreary city buildings, and some of it can be funny, cute and powerful
Response.Q6: the way gangs use it, or sometimes its offensive.
Response.Q7b: Awe. I could never do anything like that.
Response.Q8: bright blue in the first, it catches my eye and is fun purple/ galaxy styled colours in the 2nd,because its beautiful green/ blue in the 3rd,because it really the only bright colour green, it reminds me of fresh mint gum, pink. its different
Response.Q9b: It colours are pastel, they're aimming for people who like pastel colour.
Response.Q10: I can't read some of the words written in the graffiti style, but the words around them are horrible
Response.Q14: Just the basic history and about the ira and fighting
Response.Q15: They're worrying, some graffiti looks like it wants to straight fights
Response.Q16: I dont really know. A wall which separates in the name of peace never really works, how ever change anything now and violence is bond to break out

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: I like the use of colour I think it's really vibrant
Response.Q6: I don't like the crude and crass language used. But some of the overlying messages are okay
Response.Q8: The blues and greens and the complimenting fuchsias.
Response.Q9b: I think that graffiti can be very purposeful in this way and I see graffiti as a type of propoganda
Response.Q10: I like the concept of fuck peace, war isn't over and #dryyoureyes but it could be said less rudely
Response.Q14: I did history up until JC but I didn't enjoy it and I rarely paid any attention to irish history. I didn't like it so I never paid any attention. I know very little about it.
Response.Q15: It makes more sense as to why it is so aggressive. I think it is an interesting and engaging, and powerful way to get a message across on this subject
Response.Q16: I don't know if it prevents trouble or creates it. I don't know enough about it to say honestly but I feel like it could potentially create a lot of stigma around it and provoke a lot of violence and aggression and even hatred. It may keep the peace, not allowing people to interact with one another, yet it still highlights and emphasizes the divide

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: I like how the big lettering is creative in some of the images, especially images 2, 4 & 5.
Response.Q6: I dislike graffiti in general, because it is a form of vandalism, even if it looks kind of nice.
Response.Q7b: Mainly anger, because I find it ugly to look at.
Response.Q8: None. No matter what colour it is, it still counts as vandalism.
Response.Q10: I don't give a fuck about what they say. Like I said before, it's vandalism.
Response.Q14: People dying, bombs exploding, tensions between Ireland and the UK, tensions between Catholics and Protestants, all that kind of stuff.
Response.Q15: They pretty much give the impression that there are still some tensions going on in Belfast.
Response.Q16: I don't think there should be a Peace Wall. As seen in the images, people are drawing graffiti all over the wall. In some cases, walls can also divide communities, as seen with the Berlin Wall. If Belfast is to become more peaceful, a wall is gonna do nothing. It's up to the people of Belfast to make that happen.

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: Some of them having meanings behind them and stand for important things.
Response.Q6: Most people vandalise buildings with foolish words or photos.
Response.Q8: The colours in picture because they make the image stand out more.
Response.Q10: Some of them are just silly little teenagers expressing their 'love' for one another.
Response.Q14: The IRA were involved and so was religion.
Response.Q15: Some are pretty but most do not depict peace at all.
Response.Q16: Yes because the violence has stopped, I hope, and so it's a way of everyone coming together.

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: I like the colour and artistic designs in images 2,4 and 5. Its creative.
Response.Q6: I don't like, particularly images 1 and 3, the use of profanity. Not profound or artistic, just rude
Response.Q8: pic 2- vibrant blues and purple. Image 3- Blue. The green is eye catching in pic 4 and the mix in pic 5 is appealing. Don't like any of image one, atleast not as close up as it is
Response.Q9b: They are vibrant colours, would attract active individuals I would imagine
Response.Q10: 'Fuck peace'- juvenile. 'insert name and date here'- how original...(sarcasm) Some are rebellious
Response.Q13b: mixture of both school and others such as parents
Response.Q14: 'personal experiences' being a choice shows it may/is still an issue that is concerning people of this generation and is not just related to previous generations.
Response.Q15: They're eyecatching to say the least. Some are rude and juvenile but at least they show that some people still feel anger and resentment
Response.Q16: Why not I suppose? If people don't write stuff there, they will find other places to vent and write how the feel about the situation.. Although in saying that, a 'wall' is indicative of separation, not peace and unity, which is quite contradictory, a 'peace wall'. But if its there already, taking it down may cause offence. And a peace symbol is oka

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: When it is art purpose or statement purpose
Response.Q6: when its just words written like picture 1 or 3 Defacing the right walls is very relevant too
Response.Q7b: Happy or disgust again depending on the art!
Response.Q8: The block bright colours which work well together - the primary colours allow you to see and understand quicker the message if one or alternatively could be just art. Clustered or graffiti that has small writings like number one..
Response.Q9b: Because statement colours attract your eye and subliminally pass on an underlined message ,maybe
Response.Q10: written on makes it look dirty - written as the graffiti looks well presented
Response.Q14: That the English wanted to maintain reign but the people of the 6 counties were segregated by religion and clashed regularly with the english army who tried to maintain order and reign in the north
Response.Q15: I knew from looking that pic 1 was more of a commemorative piece than of the others but resonates with past memories of the troubles.
Response.Q16: yes - why not! These people have been through a lot and have continued to be segregated!! The peace wall should not be to block the communities but to bring them together. not like the Berlin wall.. more profound with more reason to commemorate those who died in the troubles.

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: political or topical issues
Response.Q6: Tagging
Response.Q7b: If it is good graffiti - inspired
Response.Q8: blue
Response.Q9b: capture your attention and make you feel emotions
Response.Q10: lame
Response.Q14: just the history of it and why it occurred
Response.Q15: a bit more meaningful
Response.Q16: No. Through history we as humans have always built walls to keep a part two groups and it never works. Example of these border barriers include the Great Wall of China and the Berlin Wall. In modern times we still have walls - West Bank Wall for example. Separating these groups only reinforces differences and increase tensions between the gorups

Response.Q5: none really - some are nice
Response.Q6: they give a bad look to neighbourhoods
Response.Q8: the pink/turquoise are ncie colours
Response.Q10: unnecessary
Response.Q14: there's still a big barrier between ireland and northern Ireland
Response.Q15: people are still anraged about what happened years ago and dont want to fix anything as you can see in image 3
Response.Q16: no, it makes no difference

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: Creativity and Expression of Emotions
Response.Q6: can be disrespectful and derogatory
Response.Q8: I appreciate allteh colours , each adds their own individual meaning to the graffiti
Response.Q9b: The artist knows the audience he/she is targeting is young people
Response.Q10: I think some are unnecessary and rude but there are names and other words which are mean things
Response.Q14: We learned about the IRA , Orange Order, the bombings the shootings , murders , rape, Border checks etc mostly violence
Response.Q15: They are ridiculous, these comments are not needed it is the past there are other ways to honour people and share beliefs
Response.Q16: No , the people will forever be segregated a physical barrier just further re enforces it. To me this barrier is unnecessary and there should be measures to bring people together

Response.Name: Anonymous

Response.Q6: The simple "scribbled" writing.
Response.Q8: The bright blues in contrast to the dark colours.
Response.Q10: A bit pretentious.
Response.Q14: Not much. I just know about the violence.
Response.Q15: They're okay. I don't think of them as incredibly profound or dull.
Response.Q16: I don't see any problem in having one.

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: in image 2 its quite colourful so that's pleasing to the eye and the colours work well together, i guess its nice to look at in an almost rebellious way!
Response.Q6: In all images bar the second one its messy, scribbles and profanities everywhere
Response.Q8: in image five and two the colours work well together and make it nice to look at.
Response.Q10: Profanities i dont like, theres no need for them, kids will be reading them and think theyre ok.
Response.Q14: What its about , what was fought for, how unnecessarily violent and aggressive it was.
Response.Q15: Doesnt make any difference to the situation really, only vandalise buildings, makes the area look untidy, it was nothing but bold youths,not activists
Response.Q16: no, makes no difference

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: Most of it is really good art and brightens up buildings in derelict
Response.Q6: When gangs use it just to write their name or when individuals use it to vandalize property
Response.Q8: the blie, it stands out them most
Response.Q9b: Not too sure to be honest! I think the bright colours attract youths
Response.Q10: I feel they're unnecessary
Response.Q14: It was mostly violent conflict between the Catholic Irish and Protestant British in Northern Ireland with the IRA heavily involved
Response.Q15: It is quite sad
Response.Q16: Yes, it allows people to express their views and is highly symbolic

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: I like the expression of art which is aloud to breath in a non restricted aspect. I like the concept that is created for a broad audience, how graffiti can reach a wide range of the public from different backgrounds and standings as it is in the public sphere. How it can reach people in a direct unapologetic manner
Response.Q6: Self obsession, "Tagging", Destroying art forms ie tagging other people's works. shit graffiti
Response.Q8: Image 1 :faded yellow/scratched paint because of the rough/raw aesthetic Image 2: purple fades and black background. I enjoy both these colours and the effect used. Image 3: The contrasting of the bold black Image 4: The yellow outline 5 pink
Response.Q10: interesting as there are small personal expression but mostly shit. The Irish graffiti scene is dull
Response.Q14: very huge question. ambiguities. shades of grey. Civil rights movement sometimes hijacked in either the "right" or "wrong" cause. Exploitation. Historical bias and favoritism. avoidable violence.
Response.Q15: Frustration. Boredom. anger. expectancy. disenfranchisement. to a certain degree passion. optimism, narcissism? i have yet to see what tagging achiev
Response.Q16: In my opinion there should be a peace wall. Censorship is the death of opinion and freedom. current events exists in a historic context. Ignoring problems creates nothing in helping to move beyond. The Troubles are recent. The peace wall is the best way to present a voice without creating resentment between people.

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: i like the 2nd one its actually art
Response.Q6: I think some graffiti makes a place look dirty.
Response.Q8: I only like the 2nd picture because it has my favourite colour
Response.Q10: its hard to understand the words.
Response.Q14: there was bombings people being killed by the IRA border control point, rioting
Response.Q15: horrible and rubs the artwork
Response.Q16: no why deface the community. the troubles are over people dont need reminding and litter the place with pointless graffiti

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: they are personal, I like the signatures all over one of them. I like colours and colour combination on some of them, the style of text used.they brighten up an otherwise very dull wall!
Response.Q6: the hashtag slogans, the plain black writing, prefer the colour text
Response.Q7b: a little defiant; proud of the artists ability
Response.Q8: the blue, yellow and orange in the first, the purple, blues and combo in the second. they compliment each other, are nice, bright, nicer than a grey wall.
Response.Q10: expressive identifying,encouraging&ordering. personal,locate people via origin&place of graffiti.
Response.Q14: causes, particular events, attempts at resolving differences, people/parties involved, effects on society&people, politics, more recent related events. rituals and parades that still take place
Response.Q15: they show conflicting wants of the people who wrote them; the wall is a place for people to anonymously express possibly unacceptable beliefs
Response.Q16: i dont know

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: I've seen some incredible graffiti that looks like it should belong in an art gallery but this is rare to see. I like to see this kind of really artistic and well thought through graffiti
Response.Q6: It takes over the natural beauty of a building or area when it is done messily without any thought
Response.Q8: Picture 1: gold, it's the brightest of the colours Picture 2: Purple, adds mystery Picture 3: No colour stands out Picture 4: Green is the only vibrant colour Picture 5: Pink, it's a small amount but still noticeable
Response.Q9b: Vibrant colours attract the eye of the viewer making it appear fun
Response.Q10: A lot are indistinguishable and probably only mean something to the artist
Response.Q14: It was a war against different religions and a rebel against control. The Catholic and Protestants were segregated but often came into contact which never ended well
Response.Q15: They make no sense although image 3, in an unartistic way, tells us that there are still troubles in the area and that the peace wall means nothing
Response.Q16: I do not understand or see the reason for it. It's not considered peaceful in my eyes if a wall is erected. It almost seems like they are further segregating

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: Colours and the text
Response.Q6: None
Response.Q8: Blues have always made me feel a sense of inner calm.
Response.Q9b: To be creative and to express there inner workings / thoughts
Response.Q10: Another form of self-expression
Response.Q14: That there are always two sides, if not more, to any one story. Certain groups in Irish and British society were not given political-economic-social representation causing an unrest within society
Response.Q15: Nothing much - another form of self-expression
Response.Q16: Yes - there should always be places and spaces in society for people to healthy express their feeling, frustrations, anxieties, hopes, dreams, etc.

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: It depends on the style and the purpose of the graffiti. If it is a simple tag then I generally do not like or agree with tagging but if it is a message or has meaning/purpose then I would like and see it as art/expression
Response.Q6: An inappropriate location like a school. A tag or gang related graffiti
Response.Q8: The purples and blues
Response.Q9b: If it is a gang related graffiti then the gang colors would be important. Signifying area ownership
Response.Q10: antiestablishmentarianism
Response.Q14: A two-sided approach about the issues that were experienced.
Response.Q15: Similar to other walls that are often tagged. Some messages have actually meaning/value while others are "tag-a-longs"
Response.Q16: If it still carries meaning and value then yes because it is an important representation of remembrance and meaning to those near it.

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: I like the fact it is expressive but It depends where it is placed .
Response.Q6: I dislike when it makes an area seem run down , so depending on how its portrayed I like it
Response.Q7b: Curiosity and wonder to what the Artists story is
Response.Q8: I like the blue colour used in the first one it makes it stand out . It also suggests some sort of coldness or sadness which intrigues me
Response.Q10: In the 3rd picture I like the quote written . On the 3rd one I'm not so sure
Response.Q14: It was a war between Catholics and Protestants
Response.Q15: Some of them are insulting to some but I also think it depIcts the strong feeling around it
Response.Q16: No because it's a reminder of off the problems there was

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: The colours the art
Response.Q6: The bad language in one of them
Response.Q8: Purple
Response.Q9b: It's an expression of who they are
Response.Q10: It's like a secret language it's directed at an audience that understands it
Response.Q14: I learnt that their was a lot of hated towards Protestants and Catholics. It is embedded In Generations of people. Living in Belfast. There is still an undertone of it today
Response.Q15: I wink don't have known it was from Belfast. Most of the graffiti I have seen in Belfast is directed at either Catholics or Protestants
Response.Q16: There should be to protect either side. There is still a lot of hated and violence in Belfast.i studied up there and know people from Belfast. There is a lot of prejudice towards each other and towards people from the south

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: Creativity, colour, art, skill
Response.Q6: Profanity, messiness, too much going on, graffiti over graffiti
Response.Q8: Blues, purples, whites, black, they are bright and colourful and blend together well and are visually appealing.
Response.Q9b: Bright colours attract the eye and would show other artists their presence
Response.Q10: Dislike, profanity, gives the artists work a disrespecful messiness. Ruins works.
Response.Q14: The marginalization of the two groups and being segregated, which caused immense violence.
Response.Q15: Generally some of them are tourists and visitors marking their names or marking their presence at the wall, it's historical in a sense.
Response.Q16: Perhaps, as it gives a sense of community with the people who have signed it.

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: The background colours
Response.Q6: The random writing. It makes it look like a bathroom stall.
Response.Q8: Image 2's background is really nice. Looks kind of space-like, makes the words look like they're blasting through space.
Response.Q10: Some are illegible, some are nonsense, the rare few actually might actually have meaning
Response.Q14: Happened predominately in the 1970's, technically ended in 90's tensions between Catholics-Protestants/Republicans-Unionists, lead to violence, bombings, IRA, UDA, PSNI, British Army, etc all involved
Response.Q15: The only one that really strikes me is the "Fuck "Peace"" one. Reflects attitudes of some people.
Response.Q16: Tensions still exist somewhat in NI. Serves as a reminder, unlike a momument it allows people to contribute more.

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: Creativity, colour, expression of beliefs and stances.
Response.Q6: Ugly scrawls with no purpose or inappropriate imagery
Response.Q7b: Motivated. It feels like a call to action.
Response.Q8: Blues and purples. They are my favourite colours and they are moody.
Response.Q10: It's hard to make some of them out. Image 3 contains quite revolutionary words. 'The war isn't over'
Response.Q14: My parents have relatives in the north so I heard personal stories of separation, tension and death. We touched on the beginning of the Troubles and the Peace Process in school but didn't focus in it
Response.Q15: It makes sense that anger and desperation and motivation are all evident in this grafitti.
Response.Q16: Yes. It allows people to express themselves in an angry manner without advertising and perpetuating a call to violence.

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: I like the colouring of the underlying graffiti though I don't find it particularly interesting as a whole
Response.Q6: The more inane tags which are over the main graffiti
Response.Q8: I'm mostly neutral except as an overall appreciation of the colouring. I do like the purple in the second image surrounding the blue
Response.Q9b: there is a purpose in the colours chosen to appeal to an audience.otherwise it's just random
Response.Q10: Some of them annoy me but are graffiti on graffiti so it's more a matter of content than placement
Response.Q14: Some specifics around events like the Omagh bombings or those in Dublin which occured during my parents childhood but it's mostly generalities
Response.Q15: They don't affect me particularly. Much as graffiti on the Berlin wall doesn't. It's a testament to a struggle that I don't feel a part of
Response.Q16: I am not well enough informed to have an opinion on this

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: I like that they're colourful. I prefer when graffiti is a bit more like art such as graffiti of people.
Response.Q6: I feel that these just aren't appealing to the eye and look more like vandalism. They're too big.
Response.Q8: I like the light blue and purple because they are a bit more pleasing to the eye and I feel that they work well together and on their own.
Response.Q9b: I think the artist tries to attract people with vibrant colours that catch the eye. So they see it.
Response.Q10: I think in image 3 the words are powerful and trying to get a message out there to other people.
Response.Q14: I learned that for many years there was unrest and violence in the North due to religion. Many people died from bombs or being shot. I learned that the IRA was responsible for a lot of the violence.
Response.Q15: I think some of them are compelling but there is definitely a few that I don't understand the point being made.
Response.Q16: I think a peace wall is a good idea and should be there for people to write messages of hope or empowerment on but if it is going to be used for people to write messages of hate then it shouldn't be. I think the peace wall seems alright so it probably should be there. I think people like it.

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: the aspects of the graffiti i like are those stemming from an artistic place, one in which allows creativity to flow
Response.Q6: i dislike the use of foul language
Response.Q8: there is an array of different colours but the primary ones stood out most for me.
Response.Q10: it is an expression. Mostly from a volatile place. Personally i dislike the use of foul language
Response.Q14: I learned about the division in ireland.
Response.Q15: acts of rebellion
Response.Q16: A peace wall is a denotion of peace, it should encapsulate it. If a wall representing peace generates just that to people then it should be there.

Response.Name: Anonymous
Response.Q5: Its a kind of art which I like. The colour, design and effort invovled in it is impressive.
Response.Q6: The aggressive/abusive/explicit language.
Response.Q8: I like the mixture of blues and purples in the first pictures because it adds to the boldness and 3D quality, and I like the green and yellow on the 4th picture just because they're bright.
Response.Q9b: I suppose because its art in its own right and every artist tries to connect to people.
Response.Q10: The first image actually looks okay with other writing/contribution, on the rest it annoys me.
Response.Q14: The nature of the troubles, the major events, the lingering tensions/etc.
Response.Q15: I think its ironic that a wall is needed in order to keep peace, its sad.
Response.Q16: Oh I think as long as its necessary for the safety of all people it should remain, while things have imporved greatly I don't know if we're quite at the stage where it can come down. It's a difficult situation... they'd want to certain that its the right time for it to come down, though I'm very glad that relations have improved.
